topic.title: HPE Helion 2.0 Development Platform: Install the HPE Helion Code Engine

ul.li: The HDP Installer 2.0, also known as HDPI, must already be installed.
Populate the Code Engine section of the clouds.yaml file.
HPE Helion OpenStack 2.0 installation must be completed. You must know the location of its services.osrc file, which contains configuration information.
You must know the NTP server and DNS server IP addresses.
You must know the proxy values and ports required for accessing external services such as Github.com, Stormrunner, or Dockerhub.
You must have an account on Github.

ol.li: SSH into the HP Helion OpenStack lifecycle manager.

Upload an SSH keypair to Nova to be used by the HPE Helion Code Engine Deployer. The name of the key you are creating in Nova (helionce-shared) must match the value of the deployer_key value in the clouds.yaml file. Since you will need these keys to access the Helion Code Engine deployer VM in the future, it is strongly recommended that you save the key files (~/.ssh/id_rsa and ~/.ssh/id_rsa) in a safe place.source ./service.osrc nova keypair-add --pub-key ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub helionce-shared
Ensure all OS_ variables are unset. Run env | grep OS_ and then unset any variables which appear in the list of results.

Install the Code Engine service installation files.
If you pre-downloaded the installation file, run the following command to install it:cd <directory where the pre-downloaded file is> openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi helionce install <filename>When installing pre-downloaded files, make sure you run the installer from the same directory where the installation files are saved. If the installer cannot find a file with the name you provided in the local directory, it will attempt to download the files again.
If you did not pre-download the file:
Find the most recent version of the file. Note that this command provides only a quick list of recent files; there are more complete listing options available that include installation status.openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi listThe output should look similar to:+----------------------------+----------------+-----------+------------+ | service | id | version | state | +----------------------------+----------------+-----------+------------+ | Helion Code Engine | wscatalog.2776 | 1.0.0 | available | | als | wscatalog.2765 | 2.0.0.539 | available | | als | wscatalog.2800 | 2.0.0.548 | available | | database | wscatalog.2762 | 2.0.0.32 | available | | database | wscatalog.2803 | 2.0.0.37 | available | | messaging | wscatalog.2761 | 1.0.0 | available | | messaging | wscatalog.2796 | 1.0.0.165 | available | +----------------------------+----------------+-----------+------------+
Find the ID number of the most recent version of the service (the highest ID number for that service).
If desired, inspect the installation files for size, version, and other detailed information.openstack hdpi show wscatalog.#### --os-cloud mycloud
Begin the download and installation:openstack --os-cloud mycloud hdpi helionce install wscatalog.#### If troubleshooting installation, turn on the debug option and run the command again: openstack --debug --os-cloud mycloud hdpi helionce install <filename or catalog number>
Launch the instance.openstack hdpi helionce launch --os-cloud mycloud deactivate
List all available machines. You should see an instance named helionce_deployer. Make a note of its IP address. source helionce.osrc openstack server list

Log in to and initialize the VM. Ignore the TASK/msg message that appears in the output. Do not run the playbook at this time; that playbook must be run later in the installation process.ssh -i helionce-shared stack@<IP address> ... stack@helionce-deployer:~$ ls helionce-1.0.0 ... stack@helionce-deployer:~$ cd helionce-1.0.0/ stack@helionce-deployer:~/helionce-1.0.0$ ./helionce-init.bash ...This process can take a few minutes. When the initialization has completed, ensure both unreachable and failed are zero (0). This indicates success. If not, check the output for error messages, address the errors, and try running the command again.

Copy the helionce deployment model. stack@helionce-deployer:~/helionce-1.0.0$ cd ~/helion/ stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ cp -R /home/stack/helion/examples/helionce/* /home/stack/helion/my_cloud/definition stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ cp ~/platform-pass-through.yml my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through/platform-pass-through.yml

Using Git, persist these changes. This information is required for playbooks executed later in this installation process.stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ git add -A stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ git commit -a -m "Add HelionCE default model"

Create a Github OAuth Application.
Create a new application.
If you are using the public GitHub.com, create the new application at https://github.com/settings/applications/new
If you are using a custom, hosted GitHub Enterprise, create the new application at https://<hostname>/settings/applications/new. You may need to contact your System Administrator to get the hostname for your GitHub instance.
Include the following values:
Field Value
Application name Helion Code Engine
Homepage URL http://myhelionce/
Authorization callback URL http://myhelionce/auth/github/callback
Register the application.
Make a note of its Client ID and Client Secret.

Return to the terminal window. This process populates the server addresses.
Navigate to and open the kickstart.yml filestack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ vim ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/pass-through/kickstart.yml
Update the following values in the file:github_client_id: <the Client ID from the Github application you created in an earlier step> github_client_secret: <the Client Secret from the Github application you created in an earlier step>
If your installation requires http proxies for access to services such as Github.com, Dockerhub, or Stormrunner, configure the proxy values.https_proxy: "https://<http proxy hostname>:<http proxy port>/" http_proxy: "http://<https proxy hostname>:<https proxy port>/"
If your installation will be using an ALS cluster which does not require a proxy, set the use_proxy flag to False. This is likely if your ALS cluster is in the same cloud as the HPE Helion Code Engine service.use_proxy: false
Save the file and exit.
Open the cloudConfig.yml file.stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ vim ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/cloudConfig.yml
Update the values for the nameservers and ntp-servers, save the file and exit. The following codeblock is provided as a sample file section. product: version: 2 cloud: name: helionce hostname-data: host-prefix: hci member-prefix: -m data-dir: data ntp-servers: - 15.126.25.4 dns-settings: nameservers: - 206.164.176.23
Using Git, commit the changes. This information is required for playbooks executed later in this installation process.stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ git commit -a -m "Configured Deployment Model"

Run the Playbooks At the end of each playbook, ensure both unreachable and failed are zero (0). This indicates success. If not, check the output for error messages, address the errors, add the Debug option (-vvv) to the command line, and run the playbook again.
Run the Pre-Installation Playbook stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ source ~/service.osrc stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion$ cd hos/ansible/ stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-pre-install.ymlSuccessful output will look similar to the following:PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** openstack-operations | preinstall | Create service ports ---------------- 5.14s openstack-operations | lookup-keystone-ids | Lookup Project ID ---------- 2.98s openstack-operations | preinstall | Ensure SVC Network Exists ----------- 2.75s openstack-operations | preinstall | Ensure External Network Exists ------ 2.73s openstack-operations | preinstall | Create Floating IPs necessary for load-balancers --- 2.17s openstack-operations | preinstall | Identify pre-existing floating IPs --- 2.07s openstack-operations | preinstall | Set Neutron Quotas ------------------ 2.07s openstack-operations | preinstall | Set Cinder Quotas ------------------- 2.01s openstack-operations | preinstall | Create Virtual IPs necessary for load-balancers externally managed --- 1.81s openstack-operations | preinstall | Set Nova Quotas --------------------- 1.77s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ----------------------------------------------------------------- 27.45s localhost : ok=20 changed=14 unreachable=0 failed=0
Run the Config Processor Play stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml -e encrypt="" -e rekey=""Successful output will look similar to the following:PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** config-processor | run-config-processor | Run Configuration Processor over the given cloud configuration --- 2.44s git-operations | _assemble-working-directory | Assemble scratch content --- 0.76s git-operations | _persist-to-git | Prep new commit ---------------------- 0.69s config-processor | configure | Sync ansible vars for cloud deployment --- 0.67s config-processor | add-localhost | Add localhost group entry ------------ 0.55s config-processor | configure | Make directories required for osconfig network configuration --- 0.33s config-processor | configure | Sync generated network artefacts for cloud deployment/update --- 0.32s config-processor | configure | Copy hosts.hf for osconfig playbooks ----- 0.28s config-processor | configure | Copy ansible hosts file for cloud deployment (verb_hosts) --- 0.28s config-processor | add-localhost | Add localhost group ------------------ 0.17s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ------------------------------------------------------------------ 7.99s localhost : ok=21 changed=14 unreachable=0 failed=0
Run the Ready Deployment Playbook stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Successful output should look similar to the following. Ignore the TASK/msg message that appears in the output. Do not run the playbook at this time; that playbook must be run later in the installation process.PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** git-operations | _assemble-working-directory | Assemble scratch content --- 0.73s config-processor | configure | Sync ansible vars for cloud deployment --- 0.54s config-processor | configure | Sync ansible vars for cloud deployment --- 0.49s git-operations | _promote-from-staging | Update branches ---------------- 0.41s config-processor | configure | Make directories required for osconfig network configuration --- 0.30s config-processor | configure | Make directories required for osconfig network configuration --- 0.27s config-processor | configure | Sync generated network artefacts for cloud deployment/update --- 0.26s config-processor | configure | Sync generated network artefacts for cloud deployment/update --- 0.25s config-processor | configure | Copy ansible hosts file for cloud deployment (verb_hosts) --- 0.24s config-processor | configure | Copy hosts.hf for osconfig playbooks ----- 0.22s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ------------------------------------------------------------------ 5.96s localhost : ok=20 changed=11 unreachable=0 failed=0
TASK: [git-operations | ready-deployment-tree-help | Tell the user what to expect] *** ok: [localhost] => { "msg": "The directory /home/stack/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible contains a prepared ansible tree ready to run your deployment. You should cd into that directory and run: ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml" }
Run the Boot Infrastructure PlaybookThis step takes approximately 5 minutes. Once this is complete, all in-cloud infrastructure (VMs, Networks, Routers, Floating IPs, ports, security groups, etc) will have been created. stack@helionce-deployer:~/helion/hos/ansible$ cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible stack@helionce-deployer:~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost hlm-boot-infra.ymlSuccessful output will look similar to the following:PLAY RECAP ******************************************************************** openstack-operations | create_instance | Create controlplane instance - 227.92s openstack-operations | create_instance | Give cloud-init time to fetch SSH keys -- 60.07s openstack-operations | create_security_groups | Create tcp/icmp security groups rules -- 34.59s openstack-operations | create_instance | Extract port-id --------------- 19.89s openstack-operations | create_instance | Wait for SSH to become active -- 17.46s openstack-operations | create_port | Update ports to include appropriate security group(s) -- 17.24s openstack-operations | create_security_groups | Create security groups -- 16.18s openstack-operations | create_port | Associate VIP to instance ports --- 14.85s openstack-operations | create_port | Create instance ports ------------- 13.97s openstack-operations | create_security_groups | Create other security groups rules (e.g. 112 protcol) --- 9.33s ------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Total: ---------------------------------------------------------------- 471.97s localhost : ok=35 changed=19 unreachable=0 failed=0
Run the Site Playbook This step takes approximately 10 to 15 minutes. stack@helionce-deployer:~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible$ ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml ... PLAY [HELION-CI-WEBUX[0]] ***************************************************** TASK: [debug msg="Congratulations on installing Helion Code Engine!"] ********* <10.241.157.75> ESTABLISH CONNECTION FOR USER: stack ok: [hci-helionci-ccp-c1-m1-mgmt] => { "msg": "Congratulations on installing Helion Code Engine!" } TASK: [debug msg="Browse to the web site at {{ HELION_CI_WEBUX.advertises.vips.public[0].url }}"] *** <10.241.157.75> ESTABLISH CONNECTION FOR USER: stack ok: [hci-helionci-ccp-c1-m1-mgmt] => { "msg": "Browse to the web site at http://10.241.26.126:80" } ...
Make a note of the IP address and port provided in the final messages from the log. This is the web site you will want to access.

Return to the Github application you created earlier and update the values in the Homepage URL and Authorization Callback URL fields based on the IP Address and Port provided by the Site Playbook. You will be replacing the placeholder string myhelionce. For example:
